title: Introduction to Experimental Approach in Development Economics

questions.question: What is the primary goal of the experimental approach in development economics?
choices: To develop new economic theories
To accurately measure the impact of specific interventions or policies
To replace traditional economic models
To increase funding for development projects
questions.answer: To accurately measure the impact of specific interventions or policies

questions.question: What is the main advantage of using Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) in development economics?
choices: They are inexpensive to conduct
They can be implemented quickly
They allow researchers to establish causality
They always produce generalizable results
questions.answer: They allow researchers to establish causality

questions.question: Who received the Nobel Prize in Economics in 2019 for their experimental work in development economics?
choices: Amartya Sen and Joseph Stiglitz
Paul Krugman and Milton Friedman
Esther Duflo, Abhijit Banerjee, and Michael Kremer
Jeffrey Sachs and William Easterly
questions.answer: Esther Duflo, Abhijit Banerjee, and Michael Kremer

questions.question: What is a key feature of the control group in an RCT?
choices: It receives a different intervention than the treatment group
It does not receive the intervention being studied
It is always smaller than the treatment group
It is selected based on specific criteria
questions.answer: It does not receive the intervention being studied

questions.question: In the context of RCTs, what does 'external validity' refer to?
choices: The accuracy of the data collection process
The statistical significance of the results
The ability to generalize results to other contexts
The ethical considerations of the study
questions.answer: The ability to generalize results to other contexts

questions.question: What was the main finding of the RCT conducted in Kenya regarding school uniforms?
choices: Free uniforms had no impact on attendance
Free uniforms significantly increased school attendance
Free uniforms improved academic performance but not attendance
Free uniforms only benefited wealthier students
questions.answer: Free uniforms significantly increased school attendance

questions.question: What was the incentive used in the Indian RCT to increase immunization rates?
choices: Cash payments
Free healthcare
Lentils
School supplies
questions.answer: Lentils

questions.question: What has the experimental approach revealed about microcredit programs?
choices: They always lead to significant poverty reduction
They have no impact on business investment
Their impact on overall poverty reduction may be more limited than initially thought
They are ineffective in all contexts
questions.answer: Their impact on overall poverty reduction may be more limited than initially thought

questions.question: What is a common criticism of the experimental approach in development economics?
choices: It is too theoretical
Results may not be generalizable beyond the specific context
It focuses too much on macroeconomic factors
It is not rigorous enough
questions.answer: Results may not be generalizable beyond the specific context

questions.question: How has the experimental approach influenced development organizations and policymakers?
choices: It has led to a decrease in evidence-based interventions
It has increased reliance on theoretical models
It has encouraged prioritizing evidence-based interventions
It has reduced the need for policy evaluation
questions.answer: It has encouraged prioritizing evidence-based interventions

questions.question: What is a key difference between traditional approaches and the experimental approach in development economics?
choices: Traditional approaches focus on micro-level analysis
Experimental approaches rely more on theoretical models
Traditional approaches emphasize randomized trials
Experimental approaches focus more on empirical evidence
questions.answer: Experimental approaches focus more on empirical evidence

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of random assignment in RCTs?
choices: To reduce the cost of the study
To increase the sample size
To eliminate selection bias
To simplify data analysis
questions.answer: To eliminate selection bias

questions.question: Which field of study did development economics borrow the RCT methodology from?
choices: Physics
Psychology
Medical research
Computer science
questions.answer: Medical research

questions.question: What is a potential limitation of RCTs in development economics?
choices: They are too quick to implement
They are often expensive and time-consuming
They always produce generalizable results
They are not rigorous enough
questions.answer: They are often expensive and time-consuming

questions.question: How do RCTs contribute to understanding causality in development interventions?
choices: By focusing on correlation between variables
By isolating the effect of a particular intervention
By relying on historical data
By using complex economic models
questions.answer: By isolating the effect of a particular intervention

questions.question: What is a key advantage of the experimental approach over traditional cross-country comparisons?
choices: It is less expensive
It requires less data
It can better establish causal relationships
It always produces generalizable results
questions.answer: It can better establish causal relationships

questions.question: In the context of RCTs, what is the treatment group?
choices: The group that receives medical treatment
The group that receives the intervention being studied
The group that is not part of the study
The group that analyzes the data
questions.answer: The group that receives the intervention being studied

questions.question: What has the experimental approach revealed about the effectiveness of providing free school uniforms?
choices: It has no impact on education outcomes
It significantly increases school attendance, particularly among poorer students
It only benefits wealthy students
It improves academic performance but not attendance
questions.answer: It significantly increases school attendance, particularly among poorer students

questions.question: How has the experimental approach influenced the field of microfinance?
choices: It has shown that microfinance always reduces poverty
It has revealed that microfinance has no impact on business investment
It has challenged some initial optimism about microfinance's impact on poverty reduction
It has proven that microfinance is ineffective in all contexts
questions.answer: It has challenged some initial optimism about microfinance's impact on poverty reduction

questions.question: What is a key consideration when implementing RCTs in different cultural contexts?
choices: Cultural factors are irrelevant in RCTs
RCTs cannot be conducted in diverse cultural settings
Researchers must be sensitive to local cultural norms and practices
Cultural context only affects the control group
questions.answer: Researchers must be sensitive to local cultural norms and practices

questions.question: How do proponents of the experimental approach suggest addressing the issue of external validity?
choices: By conducting larger studies
By replicating studies in different contexts
By focusing only on developed countries
By eliminating the control group
questions.answer: By replicating studies in different contexts

questions.question: What is a potential ethical concern when conducting RCTs in development economics?
choices: Providing interventions to all participants
Withholding potentially beneficial interventions from the control group
Using too small a sample size
Publishing results too quickly
questions.answer: Withholding potentially beneficial interventions from the control group

questions.question: How has the experimental approach affected policy-making in development?
choices: It has led to less evidence-based policy-making
It has increased reliance on intuition in policy decisions
It has encouraged more testing and evaluation before scaling up interventions
It has reduced the need for policy evaluation
questions.answer: It has encouraged more testing and evaluation before scaling up interventions

questions.question: What is a key difference between RCTs and observational studies in development economics?
choices: RCTs are always larger in scale
RCTs randomly assign participants to treatment and control groups
Observational studies are more accurate
RCTs are only used in developed countries
questions.answer: RCTs randomly assign participants to treatment and control groups

questions.question: What role do RCTs play in addressing the complexity of poverty?
choices: They simplify poverty to a single cause
They ignore the multifaceted nature of poverty
They help understand specific interventions' impacts on various aspects of poverty
They focus only on economic factors of poverty
questions.answer: They help understand specific interventions' impacts on various aspects of poverty

questions.question: How has the experimental approach contributed to understanding behavioral aspects of poverty?
choices: It has shown that behavior is irrelevant to poverty
It has revealed how various interventions can influence decision-making among the poor
It has proven that poverty is solely a result of individual choices
It has demonstrated that behavioral factors do not affect poverty
questions.answer: It has revealed how various interventions can influence decision-making among the poor

questions.question: What is a key advantage of RCTs in studying the effectiveness of educational interventions?
choices: They are always cheaper than traditional methods
They can isolate the impact of specific educational practices or policies
They guarantee improved educational outcomes
They eliminate the need for qualitative research in education
questions.answer: They can isolate the impact of specific educational practices or policies

questions.question: How has the experimental approach influenced the study of gender issues in development?
choices: It has shown that gender is irrelevant in development
It has provided empirical evidence on the impacts of gender-focused interventions
It has proven that gender equality is impossible to achieve
It has eliminated the need for gender-specific policies
questions.answer: It has provided empirical evidence on the impacts of gender-focused interventions

questions.question: What is a key consideration when designing an RCT in a resource-constrained environment?
choices: Always use the largest possible sample size
Ignore local context and cultural factors
Balance scientific rigor with practical feasibility
Focus only on short-term outcomes
questions.answer: Balance scientific rigor with practical feasibility

questions.question: How has the experimental approach contributed to understanding the effectiveness of health interventions in developing countries?
choices: It has shown that all health interventions are equally effective
It has provided evidence on which specific health interventions are most impactful
It has proven that health interventions are unnecessary
It has demonstrated that health outcomes are unrelated to economic development
questions.answer: It has provided evidence on which specific health interventions are most impactful
